docs.lead_paragraph: Update | 2:12 p.m. The Congressional Budget Office has released its assessment of the revised Senate health care bill. Find it here (pdf).

headline.main: Updated: Senate Democrats Clinch a Deal on Health Bill

docs.abstract: Democrats said they had clinched the 60th vote needed to pass a sweeping health care overhaul after Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, agreed to back the measure.
docs.snippet: Democrats said they had clinched the 60th vote needed to pass a sweeping health care overhaul after Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, agreed to back the measure.

byline.original: By CARL HULSE and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: As lawmakers prepare for a weeklong health care debate sure to be as grueling as it is partisan, President Obama used his weekly address to highlight patient protections in the bills in Congress that both Republicans and Democrats have previously supported.
docs.abstract: The Senate begins a weeklong marathon of votes on health care.
docs.snippet: The Senate begins a weeklong marathon of votes on health care.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate voted early Friday to force final action on a Pentagon spending measure as Democrats broke a G.O.P. attempt to use the military money to stall action on the health care overhaul.

docs.lead_paragraph: The longer the health care debate drags on, the unhappier the public gets. That's the conclusion of a new tracking poll by the Kaiser Family Foundation. The proportion of Americans who said they would personally be better off if health care legislation passed fell to 35 percent in December, down from 42 percent last month, while 27 percent said they would be worse off, up slightly from 24 percent a month earlier. About a third said they did not expect the legislation to make a difference to them.
docs.abstract: Kaiser Family Foundation poll finds that longer health care debate drags on, unhappier public gets; proportion of Americans who said they would personally be better off if health care legislation passed fell to 35 percent in December, down from 42 percent in November (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Ben Nelson, a pivotal figure in the health care debate, said Friday that he and Senate Democratic leaders had made ''real progress'' in negotiations on abortion that could clear the way for a Senate vote on sweeping health legislation. But he said there was no final agreement.

headline.main: Key Democrat Reports Progress in Health Bill Talks

docs.abstract: Sen Ben Nelson, pivotal figure in health care debate, says that he and Senate Democratic leaders have made progress in negotiations on abortion that could clear way for Senate vote on health bill; one of their goals was to tighten restrictions on use of federal money to subsidize insurance that includes coverage for abortions; photo (M)

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

docs.lead_paragraph: LET me start by saying I'm a fan of generic drugs. They save Americans billions of dollars each year and give us access to wonderful drugs at affordable prices. I've recommended generics in this column many times and use them myself when possible.

headline.main: A New Disquiet About Generic Drugs

docs.abstract: Lesley Alderman article on generic drugs stresses need for patient and doctor awareness about differences between generics and brand name pharmaceuticals; drug regulators and manufacturers present different stories about effectiveness of generics; FDA regulations require that generics have 'same active ingredient strength and dosage form' as brand, but doctors and other medical professionals point out that there are many other ingredients in drugs that could be quite different; photo (M)
docs.snippet: There is a gnawing concern among some doctors and researchers that certain prescription generic drugs may not work as well as their brand-name counterparts.
